section.title: Present perfect continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use have/has + been + -ing to talk about actions or states that started in the past and continue to the present. We usually use the short form.
section.text1: I started going to the gym two months ago. I still go to the gym now.
section.text1a: I've been going to the gym for two months.
section.text2: She started working here 10 years ago. She still works here.
section.text2a: She's been working here for ten years.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use have/has + not + been + -ing. We usually use the short form.

section.title: Present perfect continuous
section.sectiontitle: In the question, we use have I/you/we/they + been + -ing or has he/she/it been + -ing.
section.text1a: Have they been staying with Helen? Yes, they have.
section.text2a: Has he been sleeping long? No, he hasn't.
section.sectiontitle2: We use for to talk about periods of time.
section.text3: How long have you been teaching?
section.text4: How long has he been waiting?
section.text4a: He's been waiting <b>for half an hour.

section.title: Present perfect continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use since to talk about specific points of time.
section.text1: How long have they been standing there?
section.text2: How long has she been living in Malaysia?
section.sectiontitle2: We don't use for with all morning/day/week/month/year and all my life.
section.text3a: I've been trying to phone you <b>all morning.
